However, the argument that TFA has enhanced the status of the teaching profession becomes nuanced when we consider that traditional teachers are often overshadowed by TFA corps members, which can result in diminished value of the traditional teacher's experience in public sentiment. So in a way, while TFA might raise the status of its own members, it may not have the same effect universally for all teachers.

So, it depends on how we define "raising the status of teachers". If we're looking strictly at retention rates, then your statement holds. If we're considering influence on policy, advocacy, and visibility for educational disparities, then TFA may be contributing to raising the status of teachers, albeit selectively.
